[{"version":"8.7.1","type":"visualization","gridData":{"x":0,"y":0,"w":15,"h":5,"i":"8c286183-d630-420a-bbeb-3ce3e058553f"},"panelIndex":"8c286183-d630-420a-bbeb-3ce3e058553f","embeddableConfig":{"savedVis":{"id":"","title":"","description":"","type":"markdown","params":{"fontSize":12,"openLinksInNewTab":false,"markdown":"* All visualisation have the `other` option disabled. When searching for the top 25 error messages, you will not get an other count. This is due to performance reasons. Just delivering the top 25 is so much faster than the top 25 and summing up everything else

* All visualisations have descriptions.

* Event outcome determinse the success / failure

* Transaction.result does not need to be the same as event.outcome. A transaction can be successfull, still the outcome can be an error. For a transaction to be unsuccessful something else needs to break. E.g. a HTTP 404 would be treated as event.outcome: failure, however transaction will treat it as successfull, because the HTTP request was sent and the answer was properly parsed. Transaction failures are much more rare, since those relate to something breaking inside Kibana."},"uiState":{},"data":{"aggs":[],"searchSource":{"query":{"query":"","language":"kuery"},"filter":[]}}},"enhancements":{}}},{"version":"8.7.1","type":"lens","gridData":{"x":15,"y":0,"w":33,"h":16,"i":"b59741e7-7106-4e31-96bf-f3b29c95199f"},"panelIndex":"b59741e7-7106-4e31-96bf-f3b29c95199f","embeddableConfig":{"attributes":{"title":"","description":"Simple alerts over time. "kibana" ","language":"kuery"},"label":"Kibana"},{"input":{"query":"service.name: "elasticsearch" ","language":"kuery"},"label":"Elasticsearch"}]}},"e6c48fbb-5b48-4f5a-8446-067704db323d":{"label":"Sum duration","dataType":"number","operationType":"sum","sourceField":"span.duration.us","isBucketed":false,"scale":"ratio","params":{"emptyAsNull":true},"customLabel":true}},"columnOrder":["9e0fd8b8-45a4-404d-b750-5842084bcc33","e6c48fbb-5b48-4f5a-8446-067704db323d"],"sampling":1,"incompleteColumns":{}}}},"textBased":{"layers":{}}},"internalReferences":[],"adHocDataViews":{}}},"hidePanelTitles":false,"description":"Everytime an alert is triggered something happens. E.g. a query against Elasticsearch. Kibana waits for this. So Kibana reports waiting time, which is ok. However, we actually want to know how much time is Kibana spending as opposed to Elasticsearch. If Kibana is taking up more time than Elasticsearch, we know something is up, because querying the data should always take longer than processing. At least in my opinion.","enhancements":{}},"title":"Time spent in Kibana / Elasticsearch per alert"},{"version":"8.7.1","type":"lens","gridData":{"x":34,"y":30,"w":14,"h":8,"i":"c2fbc5fc-e6af-44d8-b3ee-9e9f19373b04"},"panelIndex":"c2fbc5fc-e6af-44d8-b3ee-9e9f19373b04","embeddableConfig":{"attributes":{"title":"","visualizationType":"lnsDatatable","type":"lens","references":[{"type":"index-pattern","id":"38466343-22db-405f-86db-dd71d7473d2f","name":"indexpattern-datasource-layer-3f9c1dd3-ae52-4bf0-9548-d91e1ee1191e"}],"state":{"visualization":{"layerId":"3f9c1dd3-ae52-4bf0-9548-d91e1ee1191e","layerType":"data","columns":[{"columnId":"9e0fd8b8-45a4-404d-b750-5842084bcc33"},{"columnId":"8647fa1c-a7e1-4e1d-a02d-91283fc39e1e"}]},"query":{"query":"data_stream.type: "traces" AND processor.event: "span"","language":"kuery"},"filters":[],"datasourceStates":{"formBased":{"layers":{"3f9c1dd3-ae52-4bf0-9548-d91e1ee1191e":{"columns":{"9e0fd8b8-45a4-404d-b750-5842084bcc33":{"label":"HTTP Response Status Code","dataType":"string","operationType":"range","sourceField":"http.response.status_code","isBucketed":true,"scale":"ordinal","params":{"type":"range","ranges":[{"from":200,"to":300,"label":"2xx"},{"from":300,"to":400,"label":"3xx"},{"from":400,"to":500,"label":"4xx"},{"from":500,"to":600,"label":"5xx"}],"maxBars":499.5,"parentFormat":{"id":"range","params":{"template":"arrow_right","replaceInfinity":true}}},"customLabel":true},"8647fa1c-a7e1-4e1d-a02d-91283fc39e1e":{"label":"Count of records","dataType":"number","operationType":"count","isBucketed":false,"scale":"ratio","sourceField":"___records___","params":{"emptyAsNull":true}}},"columnOrder":["9e0fd8b8-45a4-404d-b750-5842084bcc33","8647fa1c-a7e1-4e1d-a02d-91283fc39e1e"],"sampling":1,"incompleteColumns":{}}}},"textBased":{"layers":{}}},"internalReferences":[],"adHocDataViews":{}}},"hidePanelTitles":false,"description":"Note, that something else as 2xx does not actually mean it's broken. attributes.title: Kibana Alerting Overview

attributes.description: Those are Kibana Alerting related statements. At least, I believe so. It could also be general searches that are triggered by Kibana. The issue is, I cannot really tell the origin.

kibanaSavedObjectMeta.searchSourceJSON: {"query":{"query":"span.type: \"db\" AND processor.event: \"span\" AND service.name: \"kibana\" AND span.name: Elasticsearch*_search AND NOT span.name: */.*/_search","language":"kuery"},"filter":[],"indexRefName":"kibanaSavedObjectMeta.searchSourceJSON.index"}
